qas.question: What was heavily influenced by Christian thinking?
Medieval political philosophy had much in common with what type of thinking?
Who was the most influential political philosopher of medieval Europe?
What did Roman Catholics subordinate theology too?
How did Christian thinking differ from Mutazalite Islamic thinking?
Who emphasize the harmony absent in reason and revelation?
What medieval philosopher help to write some of Aristotle's works?

What did Averroes help reintroduce in Europe?

plausible_answers.text: set the agenda, for scholastic political philosophy dominated European thought for centuries even unto the Renaissance

qas.question: What was the effect of Averroes uses of Aristotle's works in Europe?
Who was the most influential political philosopher who made the commentaries of Averroes?

context: <a0_0>Medieval political philosophy in Europe<a0_0/> was heavily influenced by <b3_0><b8_0>Christian thinking<b8_0/><b3_0/>. It had much in common with the <a1_0>Mutazalite Islamic thinking<a1_0/> in that the Roman Catholics though <b5_0>subordinating <b4_0>philosophy<b4_0/> to theology<b5_0/> did not subject reason to revelation but in the case of contradictions, subordinated reason to faith as the Asharite of Islam. <b6_0>The Scholastics<b6_0/> by combining the philosophy of Aristotle with the Christianity of St. Augustine emphasized the potential harmony inherent in reason and revelation. Perhaps the most influential political philosopher of medieval Europe was <a2_0><b7_0><b9_0><b12_0>St. Thomas Aquinas<b12_0/><b9_0/><b7_0/><a2_0/> who helped reintroduce <b10_0>Aristotle's works<b10_0/>, which had only been transmitted to Catholic Europe through Muslim Spain, along with the commentaries of Averroes. Aquinas's use of them <b11_0>set the agenda, for scholastic political philosophy dominated European thought for centuries even unto the Renaissance<b11_0/>.
